articles.title: Donald Trump drops UFC White House news... #ufc
articles.description: Chael Sonnen reacts to President Donald Trump‚Äôs comment about the UFC having ‚Äúnine title fights‚Äù and possibly ‚Äúonly title fights.‚Äù Chael breaks down what Trump might‚Äôve meant, what details could be mixed up, and which rumors this comment helps confirm ‚Äî or destroy. If there really are 11 fights and the main card is all title fights, it would reshape everything fans think they know about Conor McGregor, Jon Jones, and Alex Pereira. Chael lays out the three possibilities: Trump got a detail wrong, he got a detail right‚Ä¶ or the entire thing is a supercard unlike anything the UFC has ever attempted.

articles.title: My pick for fighter of the year... #ufc
articles.description: Chael Sonnen breaks down his pick for Fighter of the Year ‚Äî and he‚Äôs planting his flag on Joshua Van. Four walks, four wins, a number-one contender fight that might end up Fight of the Year, and a world title victory. Chael explains why Van deserves full credit for becoming champion, why the criticism doesn‚Äôt add up, and how a rematch with Pantoja could rewrite the narrative all over again. If Joshua Van beats Pantoja in the rematch, Chael believes fans will look at this first fight very differently. Van got it right four times ‚Äî and that‚Äôs why he‚Äôs Chael‚Äôs Fighter of the Year.

articles.title: Chimaev Keeps Targeting Alex Pereira‚Ä¶
articles.description: Khamzat Chimaev keeps calling out Alex Pereira ‚Äî again, and again, and again. And Chael Sonnen believes this isn‚Äôt just random matchmaking anymore. This feels personal. The challenge now is figuring out why. Chael breaks down the timeline of Chimaev‚Äôs callouts, starting back when Khamzat was still flirting with 170 and talking about becoming a champ-champ. Back then, calling out Pereira made competitive sense. But now that Chimaev has abandoned welterweight and even hinted at leaving middleweight, the continued fixation on Alex Pereira raises real questions. What‚Äôs driving it? Respect? Ambition? Something behind the scenes? A snub? Training history? A cultural wrinkle? Chael explores every possibility. Meanwhile, Pereira isn‚Äôt ignoring him. Poatan has responded multiple times ‚Äî telling Khamzat he‚Äôs focused on Jon Jones but inviting him to 205 ‚Äúif you can get here.‚Äù He even accepted the idea of a grappling match. That back-and-forth alone shows this matchup isn‚Äôt as far-fetched as people think. Chael then explains why Carlos Ulberg, despite owning the rankings argument, isn‚Äôt generating the momentum needed to secure a Pereira fight ‚Äî and why that opens a lane for Chimaev if he stays loud and strategic. If Pereira‚ÄìJones doesn‚Äôt materialize, Pereira returning to 205 in need of a big fight suddenly makes Khamzat a very real option. This is how unexpected superfights get born ‚Äî slowly, then all at once. articles.title: Daniel Cormier says IT'S CRAZY Justin Gaethje & Pimblett are fighting INSTEAD OF Arman Tsarukyan
articles.description: Daniel Cormier IS BACK to talk about the biggest headlines in the UFC and MMA, and there is NO BIGGER HEADLINE than Justin Gaethje fighting Paddy Pimblett at UFC 326, which leaves Arman Tsarukyan out of the picture. DC addresses the decision to go with Gaethje vs. Paddy, and why he doubles down on saying it's CRAZY that Arman is being left out of the championship spotlight. Cormier believes there is NOBODY more deserving of competing for a title, and that Tsarukyan has to stay active in the meantime. DC also sheds some light on the division's future with Ilia Topuria awaiting the winner of that interim title fight. Cormier wants to know from you the fans: Should Arman be fighting for the title? Or is Gaethje vs. Pimblett the right fight while Ilia is sidelined? Watch Jake Paul versus Anthony Joshua - Friday December 19th at 8 PM Eastern, 5 PM Pacific standard time. Live on Netflix. articles.title: Islam vs Usman: This Is the Fight
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChael 170 pounds is murderers‚Äô row, and that‚Äôs exactly why Islam Makhachev needs Kamaru Usman. Not just for a payday, not just for a name ‚Äì for legacy. Chael breaks down the current state of the UFC welterweight division, from killers like Michael Morales, Sean Brady, Ian Garry, Belal Muhammad, and Shavkat Rakhmonov, to what really makes sense next for Islam. On paper, you can argue a lot of contenders‚Ä¶ but when you factor in history, greatness, and what actually moves the needle, one name keeps coming back: Kamaru Usman. Chael explains why giving Usman a title shot isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúrewarding‚Äù him for a dominant career ‚Äì it might actually be the best thing you can do for Islam. If Makhachev goes out and does to Usman what even Khamzat Chimaev couldn‚Äôt, that changes the GOAT and pound-for-pound conversations overnight. We also get into Georges St-Pierre, Khabib Nurmagomedov, and how Islam‚Äôs resume will age as guys like Arman Tsarukyan rise to the top. This is a cold sport, and matchmaking at this level is about more than rankings. It‚Äôs about legacy, star power, and who you beat when it matters. articles.title: Should Ilia Topuria Lose His Belt?
articles.description: Get 15% OFF The House of Atlas Razor Kit + Before and After Set with the code CHAEL at https://www.houseofatlas.com/CHAEL! #houseofatlaspod Should Ilia Topuria still be the champion? That‚Äôs the question circling the UFC offices right now, and it‚Äôs a lot colder ‚Äî and a lot more complicated ‚Äî than fans realize. I just walked out of the UFC Performance Institute in Las Vegas, and everybody has an opinion on Ilia Topuria. Some say he‚Äôs the best boxer in MMA, others say he‚Äôs the future face of the sport, maybe even headlining the White House card. But for the first time, a very respected voice hit me with a different argument entirely: Ilia should have been stripped. Not sidelined. Not given grace. Stripped. This person walked me through the history of the interim title ‚Äî why it exists, when it‚Äôs used, and why illness or injury has always been the deciding factor. They brought up Dominick Cruz‚Äôs three-and-a-half-year layoff, ACL after ACL, and the compassion that kept him champion. Their claim? Ilia‚Äôs situation doesn‚Äôt fall under illness or injury‚Ä¶ so why keep the belt? Now, I don‚Äôt agree. I believe Ilia Topuria has handled a tough situation with transparency and courage. He even told the UFC to move on without him if needed ‚Äî a man‚Äôs move. But the question remains: Should a champion keep his title if he refuses to fight and it‚Äôs not due to injury? This is the cold side of a cold sport. And it‚Äôs worth discussing. articles.title: The ONLY solution to stopping eye pokes in the UFC... #ufc
articles.description: Bare-knuckle wrestling is intense, but Chael Sonnen argues that blaming the gloves is a massive copout. In this clip, he explains why fighters must be held accountable for actions like eye pokes, grabbing the fence, or kicking opponents while down ‚Äî regardless of whether gloves are involved. Chael points out that referees and fans often label these incidents ‚Äúunintentional,‚Äù but that mindset ignores responsibility. Even without gloves, fighters can and should avoid fouls. The real issue isn‚Äôt the equipment ‚Äî it‚Äôs accountability. If someone pokes an opponent in the eye, someone is at fault, plain and simple. This clip is essential for anyone following MMA rules, bare-knuckle combat, or fighter safety. Chael‚Äôs analysis highlights how leniency for ‚Äúaccidents‚Äù undermines fairness, sets poor precedents, and affects how fights are judged. He stresses that proper enforcement and accountability maintain the integrity of the sport, rather than blaming gloves or equipment. For fans of MMA, bare-knuckle fighting, fighter safety, and insider fight analysis, this breakdown delivers Chael Sonnen‚Äôs sharp and unfiltered perspective.

articles.title: Merab Dvalishvili vs Petr Yan: Here‚Äôs What Happened
articles.description: Get 15% OFF The House of Atlas Razor Kit + Before and After Set with the code CHAEL at https://www.houseofatlas.com/CHAEL! #houseofatlaspod Something felt wrong before this fight ever started ‚Äî and Petr Yan proved exactly why. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen explains why the odds made no sense, why Petr Yan was being dismissed far too easily, and why Merab Dvalishvili was walking into something much more dangerous than he expected. This wasn‚Äôt a wrestling match. This wasn‚Äôt a kickboxing match. This was mixed martial arts ‚Äî and Yan fought it that way. Chael walks through what mattered: defensive underhooks, walking Merab down, the discipline of jabs and crosses, the lack of wasted motion, and the threat of wrestling that made every punch more dangerous. Yan didn‚Äôt throw everything. He committed to what worked. The conversation also breaks down the myth of ‚Äúbetter striker vs better wrestler‚Äù and why that thinking gets fighters beat at the highest level. When championship fights happen, we don‚Äôt find out who‚Äôs the better grappler or striker ‚Äî we find out who‚Äôs the better mixed martial artist. Merab fought like a champion. But Petr Yan fought like the man who had the answer. This wasn‚Äôt chaos. This was control. Only one kind of fighting wins at the top level‚Ä¶ and Petr Yan just demonstrated it. articles.title: Joe Rogan wants Gable Steveson in the UFC #ufc
articles.description: Joe Rogan says it best: Gable Steveson is an absolute nightmare for anyone in the UFC. In this clip, Chael Sonnen breaks down how the UFC could handle one of the most explosive young talents in MMA. Rogan even clipped Steveson‚Äôs last fight and sent it directly to Dana White ‚Äî a signal that this is a fighter you don‚Äôt ignore. Chael lays out the dilemma: Contender Series signings are one thing, but how do you introduce a fighter of Steveson‚Äôs caliber without wasting his talent or throwing him into an undercard he doesn‚Äôt belong on? Chael suggests a strategic approach: pay Steveson his worth, build him carefully, and consider a high-profile fight in another promotion like the PFL to gauge his readiness against elite opponents such as Francis Ngannou. If he wins, you‚Äôve got a star ready for the big stage; if he doesn‚Äôt, you have your answer without risking your top talent. This clip is a must-watch for fans of Gable Steveson, Contender Series prospects, and UFC matchmaking strategies. articles.title: Henry Cejudo‚Äôs Last Stand
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChael This wasn‚Äôt about rankings. This wasn‚Äôt about money. This wasn‚Äôt even about winning. This was about showing up when you already know it‚Äôs over. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen explains why Henry Cejudo‚Äôs final fight mattered more than any belt he ever wore. When a fighter steps into the cage knowing there‚Äôs no return, something changes. Every shot hurts more. Every exchange costs more. And the only question left is simple: How bad do you want it? Chael walks through what happens psychologically when an athlete knows this is truly their last night ‚Äî why most fighters freeze, why some collapse, and why very few rise. With a busted nose, a swollen eye, and the score slipping away, Henry never checked out. He leaned in. Then comes the bigger truth. The day of the pure wrestler is gone. This breakdown also exposes how the sport itself has evolved ‚Äî from specialists to complete fighters. Wrestling alone no longer wins championships. Striking alone doesn‚Äôt either. The new era demands everything, all at once‚Ä¶ and shows no mercy. Henry Cejudo didn‚Äôt quit. The sport simply moved forward. And this night proved it. Was it the fight people expected? No. Was it clean? No. Was it the ending some fans wanted? Also no. But when the referee stepped in and raised a hand, Joshua Van stood as world champion. Chael walks through the pressure of that moment: standing in front of a live crowd, hearing reactions you didn‚Äôt choose, wearing a belt you didn‚Äôt imagine receiving this way ‚Äî and handling it like a professional anyway. No celebration choreography. No victory script. Just procedure, spotlight, and judgment. This is not a conversation about being ‚Äúbetter.‚Äù It‚Äôs a conversation about winning. Chael also addresses the push for rematches, the injury discussion, and the anger from people trying to rewrite the outcome. History doesn‚Äôt care how you win. It only records that you did. If you love fight analysis that cuts through emotions, excuses, and fantasy outcomes ‚Äî this one matters. Only one thing matters in MMA. Joshua Van proved it.
